DataElement.preferredName: Assessment Positron Emission Tomography Other Imaging Gallium Scan Ind-2
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the yes/no indicator that asks whether a gallium scan, PET scan, or other functional imaging study was done.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Assessment Positron Emission Tomography Other Imaging Gallium Scan
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to a gallium scan, PET scan, or other imaging assessment.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Examination of the body by auscultation, palpation, percussion, inspection, and olfaction.  (Taber's)

Concepts.definition: A systemic evaluation of the body and its functions using visual inspection, palpation, percussion and auscultation. The purpose is to determine the presence or absence of physical signs of disease or abnormality for an individual's health assessment.

Property.preferredName: Positron Emission Tomography Other Imaging Modalities Gallium Scan
Property.preferredDefinition: A noninvasive imaging method that provides information about cellular activity (metabolic information).  It is used along with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) which provides information about the shape and size of the tumor (spatial information).:Imaging methods not listed.:Definition not available.

Concepts.definition: A technique for measuring the gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons (anti-electrons) within living tissue. In positron emission tomography (PET), a subject is given a dose of a positron-emitting radionuclide attached to a metabolically active substance (for example, 2-fluoro-2-deoxy-D-glucose (FDG), which is similar to a naturally occurring sugar, glucose, with the addition of a radioactive fluorine atom). When living tissue containing the positron emitter is bombarded by electrons, gamma radiation produced by collisions of electrons and positrons is detected by a scanner, revealing in fine detail the tissue location of the metabolically-active substance administered.

A nuclear imaging procedure in which an isotope of gallium is used as the radiopharmaceutical. Gallium binds to transferrin, leukocyte lactoferrin, bacterial siderophores and inflammatory proteins and thereby can be used to localize foci of infection. It is also taken up by several tumors, thus gallium scintigraphy can be used for the staging of tumors.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: evaluations of the patient and the patient's disease.
